top_comment.text: do digital forensics perform any hacking?﻿
top_comment.author: Joe Pearson

comments.text:
+Joe Pearson That is the interesting thing about forensics...  It is 
information gathering.  All forensic tools can benefit ethical hacking and 
penetration testing.  Once you have physical access, game is over.
comments.author: Jeremy Martin

comments.text:
i know they can study -- or must -- system programming but i dont 
understnad what this could benefit, i thought maybe it would benefit 
hacking?
comments.author: Joe Pearson

comments.text: What do you mean? Authorized penetration testing?
comments.author: Jeremy Martin

captions.text: Welcome to another episode of Cyber Secrets.
In this episode we will discuss forensic imaging.

Some of the tools we are going to use are free
open source tools found on Linux.

Computer forensics is a term that is used in 
many industry segments.

From criminal investigation, to incident 
response, to even data recovery.

There are three types of forensically sound 
copies.  The first is called the wrong way, so 
don't do it.
The second is a logical copy.

This is a method that just gathers allocated to it 
for later use.

For example; the copy command, or copy and 
paste utilities that are logical copy tools.

You cannot recover deleted data with this 
method since the deleted files fall under the 
unallocated space or free space.

Other terms for logical copy include sparse copy 
or even backup or archive.
The third is called physical copy.
This copies both allocated & un-allocated data.
in other words it copies all data
Bit by bit, from beginning to end.

This is an identical clone.  For example; dd, 
dcfldd, FTK Imager, and other forensic software 
contain this ability.

The term for physical copy also includes bit 
stream, bit level, image, and clone.

When making a forensically sound copy, it is 
important to have a forensically sound write 
blocker.

What a write blocker does, is prevents you from 
altering the data and protects the disk from 
being destroyed by the operating system.

In this case, I have a USB thumb drive that I 
want to connect and make a copy of.

First though, I need to connect it to a write 
blocker.
Then, connect the write blocker to a computer.
As you can see, it has popped up on my screen

In this new window, there are many files that are 
easily recoverable.

For example; I will click on a couple of them so 
you can see.

Graphic, perfectly recoverable.  And another 
graphic, Graphic, perfectly recoverable.

As a reminder, if I were to copy any of these 
files to another data area, this would be called a 
logical copy.

This method is NOT going to be able to recover 
deleted data.

Many of the Linux commands are CLI or 
command line interfaces.
The tool that I like to use is "dcfldd".

This program is an upgrade from the original DD 
command, because it can also create a hash if 
needed, that's a huge benefit.

It also allows you to see how much data has 
been copied so far.  If you type in the command 
man (short for manual) "dcfldd",

You will get a huge list of how the program is 
supposed to run.

If you type in the "dcfldd" -- help, it will give you 
another list on how to properly use the syntax.
Now to make a bit-steam copy...
First, identify in the drive.

In Linux, there are several ways to find a drive.  
Drives not found by just looking for name in this 
case RECOVERY-DR.
or by consulting your magic 8 ball.

The first method we are going to talk about is 
"df" or the disk free command.
Noticed the bottom two sections.
"/dev/sdb1"
"/media/RECOVERY-DR"
The actual drive is "/dev/sdb1"

The "/media/RECOVERY-DR" is the mounted 
link to the media.
the second method they will use is "dmesg".
or the kernel messages.
Type in "dmesg | grep sd"
that are connected to the system

If you look at the very bottom, you will see 
second disk or "sdb".

The third method we will use is the basic "dir" or 
"ls" in linux: "dir /dev/sd*" for all the sd drives.
Take a look.  sda=first drive - sdb=second drive.
sdb1 is the drive that we actually want to copy.

Now that we have the drive, we can now start 
the forensically sound copy.
Now type in "dcfldd"
"if" is for input file.  This is your source.
then put an "=/dev/sdb1"
"sdb" would copy the physical or the entire drive

This is 100% of the drive.  This grabs the master 
file table, partition table, and everything on the 
drive from the first sector to the last sector.
Adding a "1" would copy the logical drive.
This is also known as the partition or volume.

This would NOT copy the master boot record, 
partition table, the gaps in the partition, or any 
other partition with a logical drive copy.

In this case, we only want to copy the volume, 
because the way we want to mount the drive to 
recover basic data here in just a minute.
Now, let's choose the destination output file
This is going to be in "/tmp/" so it's easy to find.
and just call it "usb".

Imaging is copying bit by bit, this takes a long 
time.
We are going to fast forward a little bit.

This would be a great time to get coffee, go to 
dinner,  possibly go on vacation depending on 
how big the hard drive is.

This took so long to actually decided to start a 
movies if you see the top left hand side.

But, the benefit of the command line window to 
see the amount of bytes in and the amount of 
bytes out.

We just created that usb file and that is a bit 
stream copy of the usb thum bdrive.

Now, we are going to take a look at it in a few
places.

The first thing we are going to do is mount the
drive.
The easiest way to mount it is to create a folder,
and we are going to put it into the media folder.

Some distributions of Linux allow the items in 
the media folder to automatically be seen on the 
desktop, just like RECOVERY-DD.
We are going to call this one "/media/usb-fsc"

Notice that it did not show up on the screen 
because we still need to mount it.
"mount /tmp/usb /media/usb-fsc"

Notice on the left hand side, it should be 
popping up.
Double left click on it.

We are going to take a look at all the content 
inside that forensically sound copy of a drive.

Remember this is the DD image.  This is not the 
USB thumb drive.

As you can see it looks identical to 
RECOVERY-DR - and the DD image.  At this 
point you in a logical copy

just by highlighting everything in copy and 
pasting into the folder, or you can use other 
forensic tools on the dd image we created.
Such as data carving or other sorts of analysis.
